Juli\u00e1n Castro: s statement: The claim made by Julián Castro is that "less than half of the poorest American households have a home internet subscription." This is the main aspect that needs to be verified for authenticity.
White House: fact sheet": Castro's press secretary provided a web link to a White House "fact sheet" that supports the claim. The fact sheet states that an analysis by the Council of Economic Advisers illustrates that lower-income children are unable to benefit from high-speed broadband.
Council of Economic Advisers: report: The Council of Economic Advisers' report titled "Mapping the Digital Divide" provides further evidence to support Castro's claim. The report states that less than half of households headed by someone who did not graduate high school had a home internet connection, compared to over 90 percent of households headed by a college graduate.
U: S. Census Bureau's American Community Survey: The report by the Council of Economic Advisers references the U.S. Census Bureau's 2013 American Community Survey as the source for the data on household internet connections. This survey provides the statistical data on which the claim is based.
